source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Internal hydriding of Zircaloy cladding is a persistent cause of cladding failures

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Hydrogen pickup in Zircaloy fuel rods falls into three categories: expected because of corrosion, accelerated, and massive

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Massive hydriding is the formation of regions of delta-phase zirconium hydride in the cladding caused by grossly accelerated hydrogen pickup

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Excessive cladding hydriding was observed in both intentionally defected rods and rods that operationally defected in-pile

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Since 1960, massive internal hydriding was found only in rods that operationally defected in-pile

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Eighteen such in-pile defected rods were observed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: extensive areas of massive internal hydride were detected in 16 of them

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Both accelerated and massive hydriding occurred at remote locations from the defect

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Thirty intentionally fabricated defected rods were also tested during this period (1960 through 1970)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: The irradiation performance of these intentionally defected rods was satisfactory

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: resulting in cladding hydrogen concentrations of about 500 ppm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: 19 fuel rods (14 seed and 5 blanket) were intentionally defected with drilled holes (0.13 mm diameter) before testing

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: All 21 defected test rods operated successfully with limited radioactivity release to the coolant

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: A pronounced variation in hydride concentration was observed through the cladding wall thickness of the defected rods

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Hydrogen levels in the cladding were higher at the external surface than at the internal surface because hydrogen diffuses toward the cooler region in a sufficiently high thermal gradient

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: The hydride concentrations for nondefected rod cladding were relatively uniform

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk2
evidence_span: Hydrides in the vicinity of the defect hole were generally low in concentration with typical uniform levels of about 100 ppm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk2
evidence_span: hydrogen concentrations ranged from <100 ppm near the inner surface to several hundred parts per million (ppm) or more near the outer surface

evidence_span: Defected fuel rod; Temperature, K: 672; Time, h: 1224; Pit, mm: 5.2 × 10³; Measured pH2/PH20: 5 × 10⁻²; Critical pH2/PHo: 1.5 × 10³; Observation: normal corrosion and accelerated hydriding

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Most out-of-pile hydriding tests of Zircaloy in H₂/H₂O atmospheres were performed on coupons and on chip specimens

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Hydriding, often premature, was initiated at the sharp corners and edges of the Zircaloy coupons

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: the surface films can be listed in the following order of decreasing protection: prefilmed/autoclaved > etched > vapor blasted

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: In some tests, even scratched autoclaved surfaces were protective in the H₂-H₂O atmospheres

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: accelerated and heavy localized hydriding were produced in etched Zircaloy surfaces by scratching the room temperature film and exposing the specimens to pure hydrogen

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: when experimental pH₂/pH₂O ratios were below the calculated critical values, normal corrosion hydriding occurred

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: In tests where pH₂/pH₂O ratios approached the calculated critical ratios, accelerated hydriding was observed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: When measured ratios exceeded the critical ratios, the coupons massively hydrided

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Specimen characteristics such as geometry and surface condition, as well as environmental factors, such as hydrogen pressure, test temperature. and test time, affect the amount of hydrogen pickup

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: the type of Zircaloy (that is, 2 or 4), the heat treatment, and minor variations in the alloying additions were also found to influence hydrogen absorption

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Specimen geometry: Coupons > tubing > spheres

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy surface: Abraded > etched > prefilmed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Type of Zircaloy: Zircaloy-2 > Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk5
evidence_span: Heat treatment: α > β

evidence_span: Test temperature: as T ↑ . [H2] ↑

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: pickup fraction of Zircaloy-2 depends somewhat on the oxygen content of the water or steam, it is usually between 10 and 50%

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 has a pickup fraction between 5 and 25%

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: The coolant in pressurized water reactors contains some dissolved hydrogen (10 to 60 cm³/kg)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: Incubation times observed before initiation of the hydriding reaction were longer with increasing zirconium oxide film thickness

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: porous thicker oxide with higher hydrogen contents consisted of monoclinic and metastable tetragonal zirconia

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: Denser, thinner oxide layers with less hydride consisted of monoclinic zirconia alone

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk6
evidence_span: Two of the LWBR intentionally defected seed-type irradiation test rods had areas of accelerated and massive hydriding in their plenum regions

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: Electron microprobe examination identified Inconel X-750 constituents (nickel, chromium, iron, and titanium) on the hydrided inside cladding surface

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: Inconel-600 from LWBR fuel module baseplates can smear and mechanically bond to the bearing surfaces of Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: nickel-alloy smearing resulted in subsequent accelerated hydriding on exposure to LWBR coolant conditions

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: The nickel contents of Inconel-600 $( 7 6 \mathrm { \ : w t } \% )$ and Inconel X-750 $7 0 \mathrm { \ w t \% }$ minimum) are similar

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk7
evidence_span: Inconel X-750 $7 0 \mathrm { \ w t \% }$ minimum

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk8
evidence_span: specimen characteristics (geometry and surface conditions) as well as environmental factors (hydrogen pressure, test temperature, and test time) affect the amount of hydrogen pickup in Zircaloy

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk8
evidence_span: the type of Zircaloy (2 or 4), the heat treatment, and minor variations in the alloying conditions were also found to influence hydrogen absorption

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_020_chunk8
evidence_span: The significant factors affecting internal hydriding in defected Zircaloy rods are defect size, sources of hydrogen, Zircaloy cladding inside surface properties, aggressive fission product attack on inner oxide film, nickel alloy contamination of Zircaloy, and the effects of heat flux and fluence

evidence_span: Out-of-reactor corrosion tests in 10.3-MPa steam at temperatures between 490 and 530°C have been carried out on Zircaloy-2 tube specimens
